body:
@ijuma Good point. I think we need to fix this.

@jklukas We currently expose the metrics through `ProcessorContext` to let users specify latency metrics for their customized metrics; thinking it a bit more, I agree that it is better to expose this metrics as well for defining the sensors, and the same metrics object can then be used inside a `Processor` for recording the sensor. Does this sounds good to you?

Also since this is not a minor change, could you file a JIRA as well and explain the motivation / etc? Some related issues that I have been thinking, which we can see whether or not we should include in the JIRA or in a separate one:
1. The `StreamsMetrics` interface limit user's ability to define other metrics rather than latency, etc. We can consider let context.metrics() to return the `org.apache.kafka.common.metrics.Metrics` directly in order to allow users define any sensors following the same way as we do in `StreamsMetricsImpl`.
2. We can consider adding metrics for process / punctuate / commit rate at the granularity of each processor node in addition to the global rate mentioned above. This is very helpful in debugging.
3. We can consider adding rate / total cumulated metrics for context.forward indicating how many records were forwarded downstream from this processor node as well. This is helpful in debugging.
4. We can consider adding metrics for each stream partition's timestamp. This is helpful in debugging.
5. Besides the latency metrics, we can also add throughput latency in terms of source records consumed.
@ijuma I think it is a good practice to use the double quotes if we are unsure about whether there are spaces or not.
@ijuma LGTM
Someone who is more of an expert in shell scripting should probably review this. Have you tested that this works correctly when the path is already quoted?
Thank you @omkreddy, merged to trunk.
@theduderog @ijuma Thanks for taking a look. I've tried to clarify the relationship between connector and task states. Let me know what you think.
We are currently running muckrake with this change. https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-confluent-platform-branch-builder/28/console
@vahidhashemian Can you add some unit tests?

@hachikuji I updated the connect distributed configuration to include the `status.storage.topic`. One question is whether the status topic can have multiple partitions. It seems fine to have multiple partitions as the key we are using is `TASK_STATUS_PREFIX + taskId.connector() + "-" + taskId.task()`. And we can guarantee that the status for the same task goes to the same partition. Let me know if I miss anything. Thanks!

@ewencp Added a unit test to ensure we are not throwing null pointer exception with `SchemaBuilder` in map. Also it seems that we only check the key and value schema in `ConnectSchema.validateValue`, which makes the `SchemaBuilder` with map to pass the validation.
Hi may anyone take a look at this fix ?
LGTM. I'll let @granders and/or @ewencp take a look too since they're more familiar with the test itself.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
Given that we're doing another RC anyway, it makes sense to double commit this to the 0.10.0 branch IMO.
@rajinisivaram, one thing I was wondering is that we don't propagate the exception in `SslTransportLayer`, but we do in `PlaintextTransportLayer`. Thoughts?
Also, in `KafkaChannel.close()`, we don't close the authenticator if the transport layer throws an exception, which also looks like a bug.
Maybe we could handle both issues in another PR?

Thanks all for the discussion and suggestions here. I created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3701 and updated the title of this PR for that issue and added [WIP]. The main effect I'm hoping for is being able to define health checks for my application based on streams metrics.

> We currently expose the metrics through ProcessorContext to let users specify latency metrics for their customized metrics; thinking it a bit more, I agree that it is better to expose this metrics as well for defining the sensors, and the same metrics object can then be used inside a Processor for recording the sensor. Does this sounds good to you?

Having the same metrics registry available from the KafkaStreams instance and from the ProcessorContext sounds good.

---

Sounds like scope of what needs to change is bigger than I thought. Should I close this PR to make way for a maintainer to make a broader change?

There's discussion here in this PR thread that's not captured in the JIRA. Should I be porting that content over to JIRA?
LGTM, merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
@ijuma Thank you for merging so quickly! Yes, I will submit another PR to fix the two issues you mentioned.
Tests passing here: https://jenkins.confluent.io/view/All/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/443/console

@ijuma By "double-quoted", do you mean something like

```
CLASSPATH="first/path/to.jar:second/path/to.jar"
CLASSPATH="$CLASSPATH"  # this is fine - no change
bin/kafka-run-class.sh STUFF
```

If this is what you mean, this is not a problem. Double quotes as I understand it cause bash to interpret certain symbols as ordinary characters rather than program symbols to be parsed.

@ijuma @granthenke 
Regarding KAFKA-1508:

It would definitely be more robust to spaces in path names to have
`"$(dirname "$0")"` in all the shell scripts. However, we'd also be updating all shell scripts. It seems like a benign addition, but given that the issue has existed for almost 2 years without much clamor for change, I think we're ok without it? That said, everything I've experienced/read on this issue points to double quoting variables in bash as a generally more robust.

In general, given how surprising and quirky bash can be, and the fact that most people (including myself) have a very superficial knowledge of it, we should probably at the very least incorporate a bash linter like the one @gwenshap mentioned (I think this one: https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck)
Thanks for the explanation @granders
@hachikuji Thanks for reviewing the PR. It is updated as per your suggestion and now includes a unit test.
Thanks for adding the tests, LGTM.
LGTM

@hachikuji Thanks for sharing your thoughts and your feedback on the PR. I'll wait until a decision is made on which implementation option we should go with. I am wondering what you see as the issue with committing the unsubscribed offsets even when the autocommit is disabled. I am likely overlooking the details, but to me whether we are autocommitting or not we would want to properly keep track of whatever is consumed and so their offsets (former and current subscriptions alike) should be committed every time.

This seems fine to me, unless we also want to also add the fix KAFKA-1508.
Kafka system tests pass on this branch (these use bin scripts quite a bit), as does a run of confluent platform tests which uses this branch of kafka.
@ijuma With the old consumers gradually being phased out do you think this PR (from a while back) is still worth merging as is? Thanks.

@vahidhashemian As long as the expectation is clear to the user, I think either way can be OK, but I find it a little bit weird that we would commit offsets for partitions which are no longer contained in the user's assignment. We'll have to be very careful in the documentation to make sure this expectation is clear. I would slightly prefer keeping the assignment consistent with the offset commits so that user can always tell exactly which offsets will be committed in a given call to the commit API. 

This is why I suggested the change to use an async commit in `subscribe()` when autocommit is enabled. It maintains the current invariants as far as consistency between the assignment and offset commits, and it addresses the main problem from this JIRA, which is basically that users will see duplicates when they change subscriptions with autocommit enabled. For users who are using manual commit, they will have to call `commitSync()` prior to changing their subscription, but that seems reasonable to me.

@jklukas About the scope of this JIRA: it is up to you :) It'll will definitely great if you would like to take on this general "sub-project" for improving the metrics, but I also do not want to drag you into this if your time does not permits or you are not interested. So either keep the scope of this JIRA as is, or incorporating this general project into the JIRA and copy our discussions in this PR to that JIRA is fine.
@vahidhashemian It seems to me that it's enough to implement this with the new consumer.

IMHO, since this is a major release, now is the time to quote all variable references.  This script is effectively a Kafka API much like the other APIs.  I think users are willing to accept some breaking changes if they happen for a good reason, not that this should break anything.  Hopefully, people aren't already relying on the variables not being quoted but if they are, asking them to change that assumption is ok for a major release with the justification that not relying on subtle bash expansion rules is a much more robust API.

With a combination of quoting all variable references and checking for file existence before adding files to the classpath, I don't think there's any need to depend on whether nullglob is enabled or disabled.  It shouldn't matter.

Specifically, a file exists check should be added to the `should_include_file` function so that only real files ever get added, regardless of glob expansion mode.
@granders Thanks for taking a look. I've updated the error message.
ping @becketqin @junrao @ijuma for reviews.

We are on a fourth (going on fifth) release candidate of a major release. We need to stabilize the release as much as possible.
IMO, not the time for "lets do a larger change since this is a major release"...

Stabilizing is the priority as you said.  I view this more as a security fix than a scope expansion.  Not quoting variable references is like allow XSSing, SQL injection, etc. in a product.  I think it's worth plugging such holes.
LGTM, merging to trunk and 0.10.0.
Left one comment, LGTM otherwise.
cc @junrao
LGTM apart from the one typo.

@ewencp Addressed the review comments. The test failures seems not related to this change.  Also, started another test run https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/444/console
Merged to both trunk and 0.10.0.
@hachikuji, I updated the PR as per your comment.
LGTM, thanks for the additional review help @theduderog and @ijuma!
@ijuma Thanks. LGTM
LGTM.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Merged to trunk and 0.10.0.
To be consistent with other configs. cc @ijuma

@Ishiihara I don't immediately see how they are related, but I also don't see the same failures on tests from other Jenkins builds and I am seeing the same errors in the latest test build you kicked off. Are you seeing these same test errors somewhere else that would suggest they are not an artifact of the changes in this patch?

The empty string for the connector class seems to indicate there might be some issue getting the info into the template with the `FILE_SINK_CONNECTOR` reference. I don't understand the exact problem yet, but I think that might be the source of problems w/ tests on this branch.
LGTM
Actually, I think we should have a test for this. It's a bit odd that not even one of the stream integration tests have more than one broker, no? cc @enothereska

I had a look and it's easy to add a test in `StreamsConfigTest` that throws a ClassCastException before this change by using `getList` on the `bootstrap.servers` property.

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/445/console

An updated version of this PR, including a unit test, is available at https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1377.
Thanks @miguno, LGTM.
@guozhangwang: You can close this PR.
LGTM.
Thanks @miguno
@fpj pointed me to the page with outdated information. Review by @gwenshap.

@guozhangwang - I have some interest in improving the metrics situation for Kafka Streams, so will pursue some of the ideas you laid out. There are several potentially independent ideas here, though, so I will plan to create a few follow-up JIRA issues to discuss where this should go.

To clear, I'd like to break off discussion of the following to separate channels:
- The `Metrics` instance is currently not being closed. I've opened #1379 to address that.
- We are currently missing some opportunities for per-node metrics and other metric additions. I will plan to open a JIRA issue to discuss this.
- Users can currently only add latency sensors due to the StreamsMetrics interface. Should they have access to the main metrics registry? I'll open a separate JIRA issue for this.

---

So, this PR is still focused on the idea of exposing a read-only map of internal Kafka Streams metrics. As mentioned in the JIRA, this could be useful for developers defining health checks for their Kafka Streams application.

I'd expect a `KafkaStreams.metrics()` method to return an unmodifiable map (as implemented in this PR) because we already have that convention for producers and consumers.

@guozhangwang - Do you think we might want to reserve `KafkaStreams.metrics` to return something else (a `StreamsMetrics` instance or the `Metrics` instance directly)? If so, then I'll close this PR for now in favor or further discussion of the design in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3701
LGTM.

The change looks good although it would be good to add a unit test. While reviewing this, I noticed that there's a bug in the `close` method. We throw an exception with a misleading message if the `state != RUNNING`. We should probably not throw an exception if `state == STOPPED`.

> it would be good to add a unit test

Will do.

> We should probably not throw an exception if state == STOPPED.

Would you like me to add that change in this PR? If so, would it be appropriate to log a WARN-level message "Method KafkaStreams.close() called on an instance that has not yet been started, so there are no threads to close"?

Although maybe the close method _should_ close the `Metrics` instance even if it's not been started. In which case, the `close` method is doing something and perhaps a warning wouldn't be appropriate.

I don't mind if it's done in this PR. We would just have to update the PR title to be a bit more general (something about fixing `KafkaStreams.close()`).

The `close` methods for the various clients are idempotent, so I think `Streams` should follow that approach as well. If `state == STOPPED`, it should mean that a previous `close` call was successful so it should just return with no warning or error.

Let's see if @guozhangwang agrees before doing the work though.
@hachikuji, you fixed an issue with metrics not being removed recently. Can you please take a look at this PR?

> it would be good to add a unit test

Taking a closer look at the streams tests, it seems there are currently no tests for the `KafkaStreams` class. And I'm also realizing that I'm not sure what I'd have a test do for this `close()` method.

There's some prior art in `KafkaProducerTest` that we could possibly mimic, but that would likely require creating `MockMetrics` and potentially a mock for the StreamThread array. We might not even be able to make that work because the metrics and threads members are private, so not available to substitute mocks. There may be mechanisms to inject mocks for private variables that I'm not currently aware of, though.

Is this blocked without adding a unit test for `close`? Do you any guidance about approach for adding a test?

> The close methods for the various clients are idempotent, so I think Streams should follow that approach as well

That sounds good to me.
Right now addresses only console consumer. Will update other tools as well.

re: idempotent close(): LGTM.

re: unit test: we already have a `MockMetricsReporter` for such cases, which can be passed in configs as `METRIC_REPORTER_CLASSES_CONFIG`, @jklukas you can take a look and see if that works.

There is one checkstyle failure: `:streams:processTestResources UP-TO-DATE
:streams:testClasses
:streams:checkstyleTest[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/test/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/StreamsConfigTest.java:33:1: Disallowed import - org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.equalTo.
 FAILED`
Hmm, that checkstyle failure is from the bootstrap servers PR that I merged earlier today, my bad.
@jklukas The dividing looks great to me! Ping me after those JIRAs are created and I can help putting more content in the task description.

Thanks @hachikuji. The reason I added that check in subscribe() is it seems during the first subscribe() call when the consumer is just starting I get this exception:

```
ERROR Offset commit failed. (org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerCoordinator:515)
org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.RetriableCommitFailedException: Commit offsets failed with retriable exception. You should retry committing offsets.
Caused by: org.apache.kafka.common.errors.GroupCoordinatorNotAvailableException: The group coordinator is not available.
```

But if we somehow exclude that one, things seem to work as expected.

> :streams:processTestResources UP-TO-DATE :streams:testClasses :streams:checkstyleTest[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/test/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/StreamsConfigTest.java:33:1: Disallowed import - org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.equalTo. FAILED

Doh.  What's weird is that we use `equalTo()` elsewhere in the Streams (integration) tests, so I am confused why this is a problem here.

@vahidhashemian Ah, I see. It looks like we're missing a check in `ConsumerCoordinator.commitOffsetsAsync()` for an empty collection. We have the check in `commitOffsetsSync()`, so perhaps we just need to add it.

@becketqin What do you think about this approach?
@guozhangwang can you please review https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1380? @miguno, it's explained in the other PR.
LGTM.

@hachikuji I think use `commitAsync()` is a better approach.

I am thinking about a corner case and not sure if it is possible. The case I am thinking is the following:
1. User called subscribe() and changed the subscription, an OffsetCommitRequest was put into the queue and not sent out yet.
2. When user call poll(), a rebalance finished before the OffsetCommitRequest in (1) is sent out. Now the OffsetCommitRequest will fail because it contains the partition that the consumer does not own anymore.

Could this happen?
+1. Looks like it needs up merge.

Rebased on `trunk`, made `close` idempotent, added unit test based on `MockMetricsReporter`, and squashed to a single commit.

Thanks for the suggestions, and please take another look.

Looks like JIRA is locked down for issue creation right now, so I'll try to pick up creating the breakout issues tomorrow.

@guozhangwang - Do you think the current PR is dependent on discussion in those other issues? Or are we good to continue discussing the possibility of adding a `KafkaStreams.metrics()` method as implemented here?

@becketqin That case may be possible, but I think it might be OK. If a rebalance is already underway and the consumer has sent its JoinGroup when `subscribe()` is called (which can actually happen if `wakeup()` is used in the middle of a rebalance), then any commit is already guaranteed to fail since it won't be handled by the coordinator until the JoinGroup has returned. Alternatively, if a rebalance has begun and the consumer has not yet sent its JoinGroup, then the network layer should guarantee that the commit is sent first. Does that seem right?
@Ishiihara Since one of the tests is hanging, do you want to re-run this with just the connect/ folder of tests?

@hachikuji Agreed. I think it is working as design like you said. And it probably does not have a big impact either. I checked the code and it looks the entire rebalance process will not be interrupted unless user call `wakeup()`, so we can probably just do `commitAsync()`.
@ewencp Started another one with connect tests https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/447/console

@Ishiihara reverted the patch to dda32cc, and both of us have been doing a mix of manual and automated verification on this:
My verification is as follows:
- Full kafka system test suite against source build (all of the service classes directly or indirectly run kafka-run-class.sh to start services)
- Full CP system tests agains source build of this branch/commit
- Check external CLASSPATH behavior with wildcards with source build and a local releaseTarball build
- Compare equality of generated CLASSPATH with and without patch in source build
- Compare equality of generated CLASSPATH with and without patch in releaseTarball build
- Ran most of the connect CP system tests against release tarball (this exercises start script with external connectors)

@granders @gwenshap @ijuma @theduderog Thanks for all the reviews and suggestions. I made the suggested modifications and add quotes to all variables in all scripts. However, with this change, we do see some unexpected behaviors:
1.  In `zookeeper-server-start.sh` and `kafka-server-start.sh`, we set `KAFKA_HEAP_OPTS` with the following code snippet:

```
if [ "x$KAFKA_HEAP_OPTS" = "x" ]; then
   export KAFKA_HEAP_OPTS="-Xmx512M -Xms512M"
fi
```

If we double quote `KAFKA_HEAP_OPTS` in `kafka-run-class.sh`, Java treats "-Xmx512M -Xms512M" as one configuration and reports that it can not recognize that and fails to start JVM. 
2. Same issue with `$EXTRA_ARGS` in `kakfa-server-start.sh`

To avoid unexpected behavior, we decided to roll back to  https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/dda32ccbbd3300912c8ed05b02b0939260c04d22
as this commit passes both Kafka system test and muckrake tests. 

To ensure that the changes are working @granders and I did a couple of manual tests. The things I did includes the following:
1. Run every scripts under bin directory with source build and ensure that they are running property
2. Run every scripts under the release tar ball and ensure that they are running property
3. Passing in external CLASSPATH with wildcard and ensures that it is included in the final CLASSPATH.

@hachikuji @becketqin I am trying to write unit tests for the updated approach, but am having some issues. It would be great if you could take a look, as you might spot the problem right away. The unit test is [here](https://github.com/apache/kafka/compare/trunk...vahidhashemian:KAFKA-3664-ALT2?expand=1#diff-444ce0cab1dc8ec666294c4eafc9baefR485) and the issue I am having is [this last line](https://github.com/apache/kafka/compare/trunk...vahidhashemian:KAFKA-3664-ALT2?expand=1#diff-444ce0cab1dc8ec666294c4eafc9baefR560) does not run properly and the test hangs there. I am basically trying to leverage the existing unit tests and change consumer subscription and make sure the last read offset is committed. I hope I am not far off. Thanks.
@ewencp @hachikuji PTAL. Thanks!
@ewencp Test passed https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/447/console
